metadata.name: Factual QA Dataset
metadata.description: Factual question-answer pairs for evaluating LLM accuracy

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for water?
questions.context: Water is a chemical compound consisting of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom.

questions.question: Who wrote the theory of relativity?
questions.context: The theory of relativity was published in two parts: special relativity in 1905 and general relativity in 1915.

questions.question: What is the capital of France?
questions.context: France is a country in Western Europe. Its capital city is the administrative, economic, and cultural center of the nation.

questions.question: In what year did World War II end?
questions.context: World War II was a global conflict that lasted from 1939 to 1945, involving most of the world's nations.

questions.question: What programming language was created by Guido van Rossum?
questions.context: Guido van Rossum began working on this programming language in the late 1980s and released it in 1991.

questions.question: What is the speed of light in a vacuum in meters per second?
questions.context: The speed of light is a fundamental constant in physics, denoted as 'c'.

questions.question: What is the largest planet in our solar system?
questions.context: Our solar system has eight planets orbiting the Sun.

questions.question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
questions.context: The Mona Lisa is one of the most famous paintings in the world, housed in the Louvre Museum in Paris.

questions.question: What is the boiling point of water at standard atmospheric pressure in Celsius?
questions.context: At standard atmospheric pressure (1 atm), water transitions from liquid to gas.

questions.question: What does CPU stand for?
questions.context: The CPU is the primary component of a computer responsible for executing instructions.

questions.question: What is the chemical formula for table salt?
questions.context: Table salt is a mineral composed primarily of sodium chloride.

questions.question: Who was the first person to walk on the Moon?
questions.context: The Apollo 11 mission successfully landed humans on the Moon on July 20, 1969.

questions.question: What is the largest ocean on Earth?
questions.context: Earth has five major oceans, varying in size and depth.

questions.question: What year was the first iPhone released?
questions.context: Apple Inc. revolutionized the smartphone industry with its first iPhone announcement.

questions.question: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
questions.context: Cells contain various organelles that perform specific functions for cell survival.

questions.question: What is the longest river in the world?
questions.context: Several rivers compete for the title of longest, depending on measurement methodology.

questions.question: Who developed the first successful polio vaccine?
questions.context: Poliomyelitis was a widespread disease in the mid-20th century before a vaccine was developed.

questions.question: What does HTML stand for?
questions.context: HTML is the standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser.

questions.question: What is the atomic number of carbon?
questions.context: Carbon is one of the most abundant elements in the universe and is essential for life.

questions.question: In what year did the Berlin Wall fall?
questions.context: The Berlin Wall was a guarded concrete barrier that divided Berlin from 1961 to 1989.

questions.question: What is the smallest country in the world by area?
questions.context: Countries vary enormously in size, from vast nations to tiny city-states.

questions.question: What does DNA stand for?
questions.context: DNA is the molecule that carries the genetic instructions for the development and function of living organisms.

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
questions.context: The World Wide Web was invented at CERN in 1989 as a way to share information among researchers.

questions.question: What is the capital of Japan?
questions.context: Japan is an island country in East Asia.

questions.question: What year did the Titanic sink?
questions.context: The RMS Titanic was a British passenger liner that sank in the North Atlantic Ocean.

questions.question: What is the formula for the area of a circle?
questions.context: The area of a circle depends on its radius.

questions.question: What does API stand for in software development?
questions.context: APIs allow different software applications to communicate with each other.

questions.question: What is the hardest natural substance on Earth?
questions.context: Natural substances are ranked on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness.

questions.question: Who was the first President of the United States?
questions.context: The United States declared independence in 1776 and established its government under the Constitution.

questions.question: What is the most spoken language in the world by native speakers?
questions.context: Languages are spoken across the globe with varying numbers of native and total speakers.

questions.question: What is the freezing point of water in Fahrenheit?
questions.context: Water freezes and melts at a specific temperature under standard atmospheric pressure.

questions.question: Who co-founded Apple Inc. along with Steve Wozniak?
questions.context: Apple Inc. was founded on April 1, 1976 in a garage in Los Altos, California.

questions.question: What is the tallest mountain in the world?
questions.context: Mountains are measured by their height above sea level.

questions.question: What gas do plants absorb from the atmosphere during photosynthesis?
questions.context: Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants and certain organisms use sunlight to synthesize nutrients.

questions.question: What does SQL stand for?
questions.context: SQL is a domain-specific language used in programming for managing data in relational databases.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Romeo and Juliet'?
questions.context: Romeo and Juliet is one of the most famous tragedies in English literature.

questions.question: What is the largest continent by area?
questions.context: Earth has seven continents, each varying significantly in area and population.

questions.question: What is the value of Pi to two decimal places?
questions.context: Pi is a mathematical constant representing the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter.

questions.question: What year was the Declaration of Independence signed?
questions.context: The American colonies declared their independence from British rule in the 18th century.

questions.question: What does GPU stand for?
questions.context: GPUs were originally designed to accelerate graphics rendering but are now used extensively in AI and machine learning.

questions.question: What is the largest desert in the world?
questions.context: Deserts are defined by their low precipitation, not by temperature. Both hot and cold deserts exist.

questions.question: What element does 'O' represent on the periodic table?
questions.context: The periodic table organizes chemical elements by their atomic number and properties.

questions.question: Who is known as the father of computer science?
questions.context: Computer science as a discipline emerged in the early to mid-20th century.

questions.question: What is the currency of the United Kingdom?
questions.context: Countries around the world use different currencies for their economic transactions.

questions.question: What is Newton's First Law of Motion?
questions.expected_answer: An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an external force
questions.context: Sir Isaac Newton formulated three fundamental laws of motion that form the basis of classical mechanics.

questions.question: What is the capital of Australia?
questions.context: Australia is both a country and a continent located in the Southern Hemisphere.

questions.question: Who discovered penicillin?
questions.context: Penicillin was the first true antibiotic discovered, revolutionizing medicine in the 20th century.

questions.question: What does RAM stand for in computing?
questions.context: RAM is a form of computer memory that can be read and changed in any order.

questions.question: How many bones are in the adult human body?
questions.context: The human skeleton provides structure, protects organs, and enables movement.

questions.question: What is the Great Wall of China primarily made of?
questions.expected_answer: Stone, brick, tamped earth, and other materials
questions.context: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications built across the historical northern borders of China.
